posts.cooked: Our team is preparing for the offseason and decided to learn from some of the best robots this year and build a new robot based on that. During this process, we noticed that in many robots where the arm is mounted on the elevator (like 4414, 1678), teams often choose to build a custom gearbox for the arm joint instead of using a COTS solution like the MAXPlanetary. Is there a deeper reason why custom gearboxes are so common in these designs? I understand that the arm usually needs to be fixed to a large sprocket or timing pulley, and that integrating that with a shaft or output plate is often easier with a custom gearbox. But beyond thatâ€”for the rest of the reductionâ€”is there a strong reason why teams donâ€™t just use COTS gear stages upstream and only customize the final stage?

posts.name: Patrick
posts.cooked:
Basic packaging involves having enough space for a motor with a pinion, where both the motor and pinion have approximately 1/4-inch clearance for elevator stages or an arm. Additionally, notable that many high-profile, competitive teams utilize fewer COTS components due to their advanced design and manufacturing capabilities, enabling them to produce custom mechanisms. The potential benefits of custom solutions compared to COTS approaches are minimal.

The importance of incorporating a large sprocket or pulley with significant torque reduction cannot be overstated, as it effectively manages the required torque. COTS gearbox units and hex shafts are inadequate for handling substantial torque loads.

Max-Planetary arms don't have the best backlash, making them sensitive to even slight adjustments. They also require the use of hexshafts, which aren't always strong or stiff enough for many applications. However, custom gearboxes can be installed on one of the output gears to improve strength and stiffness effectively.

posts.name: Peter Matteson
posts.cooked: The two nailed it. Packaging and gearbox lash are the two biggest issues that drive a custom gearbox for an arm.
Also custom gearboxes are fun to design look cool

posts.name: Adam Fleming
posts.cooked: is there a strong reason why teams donâ€™t just use COTS gear stages upstream and only customize the final stage I think the strongest reason is in your question If you are spending the time to design a custom final stage then the effort to package the rest of the reductions is likely to be a similar effort to packaging a single final reduction and a COTS gearbox

posts.name: Isaac Proctor
posts.cooked: We also used a custom gearbox for our arm instead of a COTS planetary gearbox due to factors such as backlash and better integration with our design. Using a custom gearbox allowed it to be integrated into the pivot plates enabling the motors to be positioned closer to the center of the robot. This helped improve the center of gravity for our climber. Previously we used COTS gearboxes for a pivoting end effector on lifts but faced backlash issues. Generally the choice between COTS or custom gearboxes largely depends on specific design considerations and compatibility with other components.

posts.name: Yair Kornblau
posts.cooked: For us, the main reason is weight. We can usually design a custom gearbox that is about half the weight of a maximum planetary gearbox. However, wherever weight is less of a concern, such as in gearboxes closer to the bottom of the robot, we utilize maximum planetary gearboxes. For example, our 2025 climb and indexer, 2024 arm and climber gearboxes all use maximum planetary gearboxes.

posts.name: Ian Osborn
posts.cooked: There is also a package and a flexibility benefit available. Making a custom gearbox that is as space-efficient as a Max Planet is quite challenging. Changing gear ratios can be done relatively easily on a Max Planet, although this does come with a weight penalty.

posts.name: Annalie
posts.cooked: For my team, efficiency and weight are key factors. A max planetary gear has an efficiency of about 80%, whereas a custom gearbox operates between 88% to 95%.

posts.name: Elliot S
posts.cooked: We ran a Max Planetary on our arm on our elevator this year and it worked well. From my experience, backlash on a Max Planetary is much less than a non-shimmed gearbox (which we have run in the past). Additionally, in 2024, we ran a Planetary gearbox for our Shooter Rotation on our elevator. In that case, it was a Versa Planetary because our loads were much smaller.

posts.name: Calvin Selin
posts.cooked: A COTS planetary gearbox versus another gearbox.
